Award.AwardTitle: IUSE: Understanding and Propagating the Essence of Successful Computing Education Projects

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The significance of the proposed project is that it will bring together computer science education and education researchers who have completed successful projects of various kinds, and synthesize the knowledge they have gathered in terms of published guidelines for educational research, i.e., "Common Guidelines for Education Research and Development" as published jointly by the US Department of Education and NSF in 2013. While this document is detailed in general information it lacks guidelines specific to a particular discipline. These workshops will focus on providing the computer science education community detailed examples of computer science education projects which incorporate Education Research. These examples will serve as guidelines to the computer science education community.

The goals of the project, to understand, synthesize, and propagate the essence of successful education efforts, will be achieved through two focused workshops associated with major CS education conferences. The first workshop in 2016 will be more formative in nature and help develop ideas, projects, and panels for discussion at the second workshop. The second workshop in 2017 will focus on engagement with potential proposers of computing education research and will promote their adherence to the guidelines and their development of well identified educational research questions and evaluation mechanisms appropriate for the type of proposed research.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Successful computer science education projects need careful development of suitable educational research questions, experimentation, and evaluation. While development of any proposal is challenging for beginning investigators because proposals have to address intellectual merit claims and explain broader impacts to an audience unfamiliar with the work of the investigators,  the interdisciplinary nature of computer science education proposals makes them even more challenging. The goals of this project are to understand the essence of successful computer science education projects using illustrative examples and to communicate the findings to an audience of emerging education research proposal writers and principal investigators.

The central outcomes of the project are in capturing what is behind illustrative CS education projects and in disseminating those ideas to about a hundred prospective education researchers, faculty and graduate students. The project has achieved these outcomes through a sequence of four dedicated workshops. The first workshop brought together a dozen computer science education researchers already involved in successful projects on CS education. Discussions at the workshop helped distill and understand the essence of such projects. The core ideas of successful education projects, including how to develop effective proposal narratives and evaluation mechanisms, have been communicated through three subsequent workshops to a wide audience.

 


Last Modified: 11/26/2019
Modified by: Murali Sitaraman
